An **Aleax**, A, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a [medium](/wiki/Medium "Medium")-sized [humanoid](/wiki/Humanoid "Humanoid") [angelic being](/wiki/Angelic_being "Angelic being") that can [see invisible](/wiki/See_invisible "See invisible"), picks up [weapons](/wiki/Weapon "Weapon") and [food](/wiki/Food "Food"), has [infravision](/wiki/Infravision "Infravision"), can be seen via infravision, and can [follow](/wiki/Follow "Follow") a [player](/wiki/Player "Player") character to other levels if they are adjacent.

An Aleax has two weapon attacks and a [kick](/wiki/Kick "Kick") attack, and possesses [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance"), [shock resistance](/wiki/Shock_resistance "Shock resistance"), and [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance").

[Chatting](/wiki/Chatting "Chatting") to an Aleax causes it to imitate you.

[ ]

## Generation

Randomly generated Aleaxes will be peaceful towards lawful characters with good [alignment record](/wiki/Alignment_record "Alignment record"), and hostile Aleaxes may also appear as [minions](/wiki/Minion "Minion") of a lawful god. Aleaxes are never randomly generated in [Gehennom](/wiki/Gehennom "Gehennom").

An Aleax is [generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") an uncursed [erodeproof](/wiki/Erodeproof "Erodeproof") [large shield](/wiki/Large_shield "Large shield") 3⁄4 of the time, and an uncursed [shield of reflection](/wiki/Shield_of_reflection "Shield of reflection") otherwise, and their weapon will be a blessed erodeproof [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword"), with a 1⁄5 chance of the sword being either [Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane") or [Sunsword](/wiki/Sunsword "Sunsword") if neither artifact has been generated.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([NetHack 3.7](/wiki/NetHack_3.7 "NetHack 3.7")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

Aleaxes can only receive Sunsword, as Demonbane's base item is changed to a [mace](/wiki/Mace "Mace").

## Strategy

Aleaxes possess a decent [AC](/wiki/AC "AC") of 0 and their long swords are often enchanted, and their [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") of 30 confers significant resistance to some [spells](/wiki/Spell "Spell") and [wands](/wiki/Wand "Wand") - however, they move at a slow 8 [speed](/wiki/Speed "Speed"), and usually are not too dangerous for a character deep enough in the dungeon to encounter one. Even so, an Aleax should be handled with some caution, especially if a hostile one generates with a shield of reflection.

Of note is that the Aleax is the only humanoid angelic being to be a valid form for [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph").

## History

The [Aleax]() first appears in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0").

## Origin

In *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, an Aleax is an avatar of a deity sent to punish a specific mortal. *Dungeons & Dragons* pluralizes the being's name as **Aleaxi**[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) - *NetHack* instead pluralizes their name as **Aleaxes**.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

The Aleax takes on the target's exact appearance and carries identical equipment, which is why the Aleax of *NetHack* imitates you when spoken to.

## Messages

- \<The Aleax> imitates you.

  You chatted to an Aleax.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the Aleax's [difficulty](/wiki/Monster_difficulty "Monster difficulty") is raised to 15, and [requires a +2 weapon or better](/wiki/Need_%2Bx_weapon_to_hit "Need +x weapon to hit") to be hit, while implicitly [hitting as a +2 weapon](/wiki/Hits_creatures_as_%2Bx_weapon "Hits creatures as +x weapon").

Aleaxes and Angels are the only angelic beings that cannot be gifted as minions to lawful characters via [sacrifice](/wiki/Sacrifice "Sacrifice") or [prayer](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer").

All of the above information also applies to [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM").

### GruntHack

In [GruntHack](/wiki/GruntHack "GruntHack"), the Aleax's difficulty is lowered to 11.

### SporkHack

In [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack"), the Aleax's weapon attacks are buffed to 2d6.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), the Aleax uses the A glyph. A randomly generated Aleax is created with [erodeproof](/wiki/Erodeproof "Erodeproof") +0 copies of all of the player's equipment and weapons being worn at the time of its generation, with any [artifacts](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") converted to their [base items](/wiki/Base_item "Base item"). This behavior is adapted from *Dungeons & Dragons*, as described [above](#Origin).

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack") and [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack"), the Aleax uses the 7 glyph. Their difficulty is raised to 13, their 10 points of AC are all from divine protection, and they are made invalid forms for polymorph - their two weapon attacks are changed to "mirror" attacks with the same dice that use a copy of your current weapon.

Three hostile Aleaxes appear within one of the rooms in [Demogorgon](/wiki/Demogorgon "Demogorgon")'s lair if his dwelling appears as [the third Abyss level](/wiki/User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Brine_Flats#Demogorgon.27s_palace "User:Chris/dNetHack/Branches/Brine Flats").

## Encyclopedia entry

Said to be a doppelganger sent to inflict divine punishment for alignment violations.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 326](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L326)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) David "Zeb" Cook (1994). Planescape Campaign Setting, Monstrous Supplement. Edited by David Wise. (TSR, Inc), pp. 2–3. ISBN 978-1560768340.
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mondata.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 760](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mondata.c#L760)
